                                                    Politico
A daily download of technology news from Washington and Silicon Valley

            By 
Adam Sneed

09/15/15, 10:02 AM EDT
With help from Brooks Boliek and Kate Tummarello.
ISAACSON PASSES ON LIBRARIAN OF CONGRESS — It looks like one person floated for the top spot at the Library of Congress has taken himself out of the running. Nancy reports that Walter Isaacson, CEO of the Aspen Institute and famed biographer of Steve Jobs, was approached by people close to the White House about filling the post. Current Librarian James Billington is retiring at the end of the year after 28 years on the job. Isaacson, maybe the highest-profile name rumored for the spot, decided not to go forward with it, Nancy writes. 
The White House has faced pressure from tech groups and others to pick someone who can fix the Library’s reputation as an arcane, tech-averse institution and, among other things, prepare it to deal with copyright policy in the digital age.
“According to a source familiar with the process, the White House is hunting for someone to fill the position that meets a varied set of criteria: The person should be something of a public intellectual with a scholarly bent, know how to manage a sprawling institution, and have an understanding of the complexities of both copyright policy and public access to information in the digital age,” Nancy writes. More, for Pros: http://politico.pro/1Y5Arvp 
GOOD TUESDAY MORNING and welcome to Morning Tech, where we’re going to start thinking twice before wishing on a shooting star. NASA’s new infographic about the “#YearInSpace” mission includes the unfortunate detail that human waste from the International Space Station is propelled back to Earth, and it looks as magical as anything else along the way: http://bit.ly/1icHilL. Send news, tips and anything your heart desires to asneed@politico.com and follow @atsneed and @MorningTech. Catch the full team’s info after speed read.
FANTASY SPORTS, REAL GAMBLING? — Fantasy sports are all the rage this fall, but what makes them different from prohibited forms of online gambling? That’s what Rep. Frank Pallone, the top Democrat on the House Energy & Commerce Committee, wants to know, and he’s asking for a hearing to discuss it. The legal landscape surrounding fantasy sports is “murky,” making it “ripe for congressional review,” Pallone said Monday in a letter (http://1.usa.gov/1Qdb3OG) to committee leadership. 
He’s pointing to three separate laws, including the Interstate Wire Act, that ban interstate gambling and sports betting online, but also run up against a carve-out for fantasy sports in the Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act. Another area of concern, he said, is how cozy professional sports leagues are getting with fantasy sports networks. He’s also questioning whether pro athletes and league personnel, “who may be able to affect the outcome of a game,” should be able to take part. Don’t bet on swift action that threatens fantasy sports, but we’re tracking to see if a hearing reaches the books.
HOW ABOUT FANTASY POLITICS? — For a short while, it looked like there might be another ostentatious billionaire — and another tech figure — in the 2016 circus. Alas, Mark Cuban told CNBC that he’s “not at all” considering a run for the White House (http://bit.ly/1M7ATTb), despite saying earlier that he’d easily beat Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton (http://for.tn/1M7BhRE). Cuban did tell POLITICO’s Ben Schreckinger he’d be open to serving in a Trump administration “if he promises to do exactly what I tell him to do” (http://politi.co/1M7CQix) — so it’s safe to bet that won’t happen. But with Republican Carly Fiorina, Democrat Larry Lessig and “Cyber Party” candidate John McAfee, there are plenty of long-shot techies to keep track of, and only (ugh) 419 days until Election Day.
FCC TO COURT: NET NEUTRALITY RULES ARE ‘NECESSARY SOLUTIONS’ — The FCC dropped a 218-page filing with the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia on Monday night arguing the agency “has the authority to ensure that the Internet, the central means of communication in the 21st century, remains open to all Americans.” Dropping the names of Google, Amazon, Apple and Netflix, the commission told the court it should reject a legal challenge to the controversial rules lodged earlier this year by several large telecommunications trade groups and some of their members.
“It is the Order — not USTelecom’s rhetoric — that is before this Court,” the FCC argues in the brief. “The Order concludes that the Internet ‘must remain open: open for commerce, innovation and speech; open for consumers and for the innovation created by applications developers and content companies; and open for expansion and investment by America’s broadband providers.”’
The commission argues its net neutrality rules are “focusing on the threats to Internet openness” but “using a light-touch version of Title II.” The filing: http://bit.ly/1EZ2TZM 
TODAY: PAI ROAD TRIP TO FARGO — Republican FCC Commissioner Ajit Pai will make an appearance in the Upper Midwest today, joining Rep. Kevin Cramer for a series of meetings and speeches in Fargo, N.D.. It’s Pai’s second appearance with a Republican lawmaker in two days (he spent Monday with Sen. Steve Daines in Montana). Pai is scheduled to speak at the Fargo Connect luncheon. Among the issues likely to come up: plans to reform the Universal Service Fund, which Cramer has raised in FCC hearings at the House Energy & Commerce subcommittee on telecommunications. 
HOUSE JUDICIARY EYEING THURSDAY MARKUP — The House Judiciary Committee is planning to mark up the Judicial Redress Act on Thursday, sources tell Kate, who had the scoop late Monday afternoon. The tech industry has supported the bill, which would extend some privacy protections to citizens of U.S. allies. The bill -- or something like it -- is critical to closing a deal reached by U.S. and EU officials last week on data protection. The committee hasn’t announced details yet, but we’re tracking. For pros: http://politico.pro/1NsGO6U 
IA’S BAY STATE WARNING — The Internet Association is taking issue with proposals in the Massachusetts Legislature that it says would place burdensome regulations on ride-hailing services (and IA members) Uber, Lyft and Sidecar. The trade group is urging lawmakers on the Massachusetts Joint Committee on Financial Services to reject measures backed by the taxi industry that would require fingerprint background checks on drivers and outlaw surge pricing. Uber has threatened to stop operating in the state if those measures are approved. 
Uber is backing a bill by Gov. Charlie Baker that would require background checks, insurance for riders and drivers, and assign the state’s Department of Public Utilities as a regulator. IA President Michael Beckerman writes that any measures beyond that would “require duplicative and expensive procedures that add bureaucracy at the expense of innovation.” The letter: http://bit.ly/1M7GF7i 
SURVEY: VENTURE CAPITALISTS TRACKING IMMIGRATION, IoT — Venture capitalists reported low confidence in the federal government’s ability to enact policies that support their work in the next year, according to a report out this morning by Deloitte and the National Venture Capital Association. Immigration is their top policy concern, with over 60 percent of those surveyed saying they want to see reforms — a cause the tech industry has championed because of its need for visas for high-skilled workers. Another key finding: Cloud computing still holds its place as the strongest sector for tech investment, with mobile technologies finishing in a close second. Biotech, clean energy and the Internet of Things also featured high on VCs’ radar. See the full report here: http://bit.ly/1EZ47UN
SPEED READ
COPYRIGHT RULING BOOSTS FAIR USE IN DMCA CASES. A federal court says rights-holders must consider fair use before filing takedown requests on infringement grounds. The New York Times reports: http://nyti.ms/1icEpS9 
WYDEN OUTLINES HIS CISA PLAN. He likens the cybersecurity bill to “responding to a bear attack by stockpiling honey” and says he “will not casually give up” his amendments to a “flawed bill.” The Daily Dot has more: http://bit.ly/1icDOQc 
APPLE HASN’T SLOWED SPOTIFY. The streaming service says its growth rate has increased since Apple Music launched in June and that it’s still “setting new records week by week.” Bloomberg reports: http://bloom.bg/1icEHbz
TWITTER GETS A SMARTER ‘BUY’ BUTTON. The social network will integrate new features from payment startup Stripe, which lets companies sell products on mobile platforms. The Wall Street Journal has the details: http://on.wsj.com/1icFFEJ 
Tips, comments, suggestions? Send them along via email to our team: Alex Byers (abyers@politico.com, @byersalex), Eric Engleman (eengleman@politico.com, @ericengleman), Amy Schatz (aschatz@politico.com, @amy_schatz),Brooks Boliek (bboliek@politico.com, @technocowboy), Tony Romm (tromm@politico.com, @tonyromm), Kate Tummarello (ktummarello@politico.com, @ktummarello), Nancy Scola (nscola@politico.com, @nancyscola) and Adam Sneed (asneed@politico.com, @atsneed).
DEBRIEF INTERVIEW WITH STAN COLLENDER: What’s at stake in the budget showdown on Capitol Hill? The renowned budget expert tells us how the protracted negotiations hurt government agencies, weighs the consequences of a government shutdown and fills us in on which key players he’s watching right now. Find out on this week’s Debrief video from The Agenda: http://politi.co/1KnnC9N 

                                            By 
                                                    Ian Bremmer


                                            By 
Blake Hounshell


                                            By 
                                                    Jason Zengerle


                                            By 
                                                    Daniel Yergin

Adam Sneed is a technology reporter for POLITICO Pro. Before joining POLITICO as a Web producer in 2013, he spent two years at the New America Foundation’s Future Tense initiative, covering science and technology policy in partnership with Slate magazine and Arizona State University. As a student at Arizona State, he was editor-in-chief of The State Press and held reporting internships at the Arizona Guardian and Arizona Republic. He graduated in May 2011 with degrees in journalism and political science.

description: Pallone wants to talk fantasy sports — FCC lays out net neutrality arguments
title: Isaacson passes on Librarian of Congress
